Detailed Description

Manages a TCP connection. This class itself implements the TCP state machine as well as handling control PDUs (SYN, SYN+ACK, RST, FIN, etc.), timers (2MSL, CONN-ESTAB, FIN-WAIT-2) and events (OPEN, SEND, etc) associated with TCP state changes.

The implementation largely follows the functional specification at the end of RFC 793. Code comments extensively quote RFC 793 to make it easier to understand.

TCPConnection objects are not used alone -- they are instantiated and managed by a TCP module.

TCPConnection "outsources" several tasks to objects subclassed from TCPSendQueue, TCPReceiveQueue and TCPAlgorithm; see overview of this with TCP documentation.

Connection variables (TCB) are kept in TCPStateVariables. TCPAlgorithm implementations can extend TCPStateVariables to add their own stuff (see TCPAlgorithm::createStateVariables() factory method.)

The "entry points" of TCPConnnection from TCP are:

  • processTimer(cMessage *msg): handle self-messages which belong to the connection
  • processTCPSegment(TCPSegment *tcpSeg, IPvXAddress srcAddr, IPvXAddress destAddr): handle segment arrivals
  • processAppCommand(cMessage *msg): process commands which arrive from the application (TCP_C_xxx)

All three methods follow a common structure:

  1. dispatch to specific methods. For example, processAppCommand() invokes one of process_OPEN_ACTIVE(), process_OPEN_PASSIVE() or process_SEND(), etc., and processTCPSegment() dispatches to processSegmentInListen(), processSegmentInSynSent() or processSegment1stThru8th(). Those methods will do the REAL JOB.
  2. after they return, we'll know the state machine event (TCPEventCode, TCP_E_xxx) for sure, so we can:
  3. invoke performStateTransition() which executes the necessary state transition (for example, TCP_E_RCV_SYN will take the state machine from TCP_S_LISTEN to TCP_S_SYN_RCVD). No other actions are taken in this step.
  4. if there was a state change (for example, we entered the TCP_S_ESTABLISHED state), performStateTransition() invokes stateEntered(), which performs some necessary housekeeping (cancel the CONN-ESTAB timer).

When the CLOSED state is reached, TCP will delete the TCPConnection object.

00400                 case TCP_E_RCV_UNEXP_SYN: FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00401                 default:;
00402             }
00403             break;
00404 
00405         case TCP_S_CLOSING:
00406             switch (event)
00407             {
00408                 case TCP_E_ABORT:       FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00409                 case TCP_E_RCV_ACK:     FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_TIME_WAIT); break;
00410                 case TCP_E_RCV_RST:     FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00411                 case TCP_E_RCV_UNEXP_SYN: FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00412                 default:;
00413             }
00414             break;
00415 
00416         case TCP_S_TIME_WAIT:
00417             switch (event)
00418             {
00419                 case TCP_E_ABORT:       FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00420                 case TCP_E_TIMEOUT_2MSL: FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00421                 case TCP_E_RCV_RST:     FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00422                 case TCP_E_RCV_UNEXP_SYN: FSM_Goto(fsm, TCP_S_CLOSED); break;
00423                 default:;
00424             }
00425             break;
00426 
00427         case TCP_S_CLOSED:
00428             break;
00429     }
00430 
00431     if (oldState!=fsm.getState())
00432     {
00433         tcpEV << "Transition: " << stateName(oldState) << " --> " << stateName(fsm.getState()) << "  (event was: " << eventName(event) << ")\n";
00434         testingEV << tcpMain->getName() << ": " << stateName(oldState) << " --> " << stateName(fsm.getState()) << "  (on " << eventName(event) << ")\n";
00435 
00436         // cancel timers, etc.
00437         stateEntered(fsm.getState());
00438     }
00439     else
00440     {
00441         tcpEV << "Staying in state: " << stateName(fsm.getState()) << " (event was: " << eventName(event) << ")\n";
00442     }
00443 
00444     return fsm.getState()!=TCP_S_CLOSED;
00445 }

bool TCPConnection::processAckInEstabEtc ( TCPSegment *  tcpseg  )  [protected, virtual]

Definition at line 920 of file old/TCPConnectionRcvSegment.cc.

Referenced by processSegment1stThru8th().

00921 {
00922     tcpEV2 << "Processing ACK in a data transfer state\n";
00923 
00924     //
00925     //"
00926     //  If SND.UNA < SEG.ACK =< SND.NXT then, set SND.UNA <- SEG.ACK.
00927     //  Any segments on the retransmission queue which are thereby
00928     //  entirely acknowledged are removed.  Users should receive
00929     //  positive acknowledgments for buffers which have been SENT and
00930     //  fully acknowledged (i.e., SEND buffer should be returned with
00931     //  "ok" response).  If the ACK is a duplicate
00932     //  (SEG.ACK < SND.UNA), it can be ignored.  If the ACK acks
00933     //  something not yet sent (SEG.ACK > SND.NXT) then send an ACK,
00934     //  drop the segment, and return.
00935     //
00936     //  If SND.UNA < SEG.ACK =< SND.NXT, the send window should be
00937     //  updated.  If (SND.WL1 < SEG.SEQ or (SND.WL1 = SEG.SEQ and
00938     //  SND.WL2 =< SEG.ACK)), set SND.WND <- SEG.WND, set
00939     //  SND.WL1 <- SEG.SEQ, and set SND.WL2 <- SEG.ACK.
00940     //
00941     //  Note that SND.WND is an offset from SND.UNA, that SND.WL1
00942     //  records the sequence number of the last segment used to update
00943     //  SND.WND, and that SND.WL2 records the acknowledgment number of
00944     //  the last segment used to update SND.WND.  The check here
00945     //  prevents using old segments to update the window.
00946     //"
00947     // Note: should use SND.MAX instead of SND.NXT in above checks
00948     //
00949     if (seqGE(state->snd_una, tcpseg->getAckNo()))
00950     {
00951         //
00952         // duplicate ACK? A received TCP segment is a duplicate ACK if all of
00953         // the following apply:
00954         //    (1) snd_una==ackNo
00955         //    (2) segment contains no data
00956         //    (3) there's unacked data (snd_una!=snd_max)
00957         //
00958         // Note: ssfnet uses additional constraint "window is the same as last
00959         // received (not an update)" -- we don't do that because window updates
00960         // are ignored anyway if neither seqNo nor ackNo has changed.
00961         //
00962         if (state->snd_una==tcpseg->getAckNo() && tcpseg->getPayloadLength()==0 &&
00963             state->snd_una!=state->snd_max)
00964         {
00965             state->dupacks++;
00966             tcpAlgorithm->receivedDuplicateAck();
00967         }
00968         else
00969         {
00970             // if doesn't qualify as duplicate ACK, just ignore it.
00971             if (tcpseg->getPayloadLength()==0)
00972             {
00973                 if (state->snd_una!=tcpseg->getAckNo())
00974                     tcpEV << "Old ACK: ackNo<snd_una\n";
00975                 else if (state->snd_una==state->snd_max)
00976                     tcpEV << "ACK looks duplicate but we have currently no unacked data (snd_una==snd_max)\n";
00977             }
00978 
00979             // reset counter
00980             state->dupacks = 0;
00981         }
00982     }
00983     else if (seqLE(tcpseg->getAckNo(), state->snd_max))
00984     {
00985         // ack in window.
00986         uint32 old_snd_una = state->snd_una;
00987         state->snd_una = tcpseg->getAckNo();
00988         if (unackedVector) unackedVector->record(state->snd_max - state->snd_una);
00989 
00990         // after retransmitting a lost segment, we may get an ack well ahead of snd_nxt
00991         if (seqLess(state->snd_nxt, state->snd_una))
00992             state->snd_nxt = state->snd_una;
00993 
00994         uint32 discardUpToSeq = state->snd_una;
00995 
00996         // our FIN acked?
00997         if (state->send_fin && tcpseg->getAckNo()==state->snd_fin_seq+1)
00998         {
00999             // set flag that our FIN has been acked
01000             tcpEV << "ACK acks our FIN\n";
01001             state->fin_ack_rcvd = true;
01002             discardUpToSeq--; // the FIN sequence number is not real data
01003         }
01004 
01005         // acked data no longer needed in send queue
01006         sendQueue->discardUpTo(discardUpToSeq);
01007 
01008         if (seqLess(state->snd_wl1, tcpseg->getSequenceNo()) ||
01009             (state->snd_wl1==tcpseg->getSequenceNo() && seqLE(state->snd_wl2, tcpseg->getAckNo())))
01010         {
01011             // send window should be updated
01012             tcpEV << "Updating send window from segment: new wnd=" << tcpseg->getWindow() << "\n";
01013             state->snd_wnd = tcpseg->getWindow();
01014             state->snd_wl1 = tcpseg->getSequenceNo();
01015             state->snd_wl2 = tcpseg->getAckNo();
01016             if (sndWndVector) sndWndVector->record(state->snd_wnd);
01017         }
01018 
01019         // notify
01020         tcpAlgorithm->receivedDataAck(old_snd_una);
01021 
01022         // in the receivedDataAck we need the old value
01023         state->dupacks = 0;
01024     }
01025     else
01026     {
01027         ASSERT(seqGreater(tcpseg->getAckNo(), state->snd_max)); // from if-ladder
01028 
01029         // send an ACK, drop the segment, and return.
01030         tcpAlgorithm->receivedAckForDataNotYetSent(tcpseg->getAckNo());
01031         state->dupacks = 0;
01032         return false;  // means "drop"
01033     }
01034     return true;
01035 }

00550                     // Restart the 2 MSL time-wait timeout.
00551                     cancelEvent(the2MSLTimer);
00552                     scheduleTimeout(the2MSLTimer, TCP_TIMEOUT_2MSL);
00553                     break;
00554             }
00555             sendIndicationToApp(TCP_I_PEER_CLOSED);
00556         }
00557         else
00558         {
00559             // we'll have to do it later (when an arriving segment "fills the gap")
00560             tcpEV << "FIN segment above sequence, storing sequence number of FIN\n";
00561             state->fin_rcvd = true;
00562             state->rcv_fin_seq = fin_seq;
00563         }
00564 
00565         // TBD do PUSH stuff
00566     }
00567 
00568     if (old_rcv_nxt!=state->rcv_nxt)
00569     {
00570         // if rcv_nxt changed, either because we received segment text or we
00571         // received a FIN that needs to be acked (or both), we need to send or
00572         // schedule an ACK.
00573 
00574         // tcpAlgorithm decides when and how to do ACKs
00575         tcpAlgorithm->receiveSeqChanged();
00576     }
00577 
00578     if ((fsm.getState()==TCP_S_ESTABLISHED || fsm.getState()==TCP_S_SYN_RCVD) &&
00579         state->send_fin && state->snd_nxt==state->snd_fin_seq+1)
00580     {
00581         // if the user issued the CLOSE command a long time ago and we've just
00582         // managed to send off FIN, we simulate a CLOSE command now (we had to
00583         // defer it at that time because we still had data in the send queue.)
00584         // This CLOSE will take us into the FIN_WAIT_1 state.
00585         tcpEV << "Now we can do the CLOSE which was deferred a while ago\n";
00586         event = TCP_E_CLOSE;
00587     }
00588 
00589     if (fsm.getState()==TCP_S_CLOSE_WAIT && state->send_fin &&
00590         state->snd_nxt==state->snd_fin_seq+1 && old_snd_nxt!=state->snd_nxt)
00591     {
00592         // if we're in CLOSE_WAIT and we just got to sent our long-pending FIN,
00593         // we simulate a CLOSE command now (we had to defer it at that time because
00594         // we still had data in the send queue.) This CLOSE will take us into the
00595         // LAST_ACK state.
00596         tcpEV << "Now we can do the CLOSE which was deferred a while ago\n";
00597         event = TCP_E_CLOSE;
00598     }
00599 
00600     return event;
00601 }

00485         return false;
00486 
00487     // maxWindow is smaller of (snd_wnd, congestionWindow)
00488     long maxWindow = state->snd_wnd;
00489     if (congestionWindow>=0 && maxWindow > congestionWindow)
00490         maxWindow = congestionWindow;
00491 
00492     // effectiveWindow: number of bytes we're allowed to send now
00493     long effectiveWin = maxWindow - (state->snd_nxt - state->snd_una);
00494     if (effectiveWin <= 0)
00495     {
00496         tcpEV << "Effective window is zero (advertised window " << state->snd_wnd <<
00497                  ", congestion window " << congestionWindow << "), cannot send.\n";
00498         return false;
00499     }
00500 
00501     ulong bytesToSend = effectiveWin;
00502 
00503     if (bytesToSend > buffered)
00504         bytesToSend = buffered;
00505 
00506     if (fullSegmentsOnly && bytesToSend < state->snd_mss && buffered > (ulong) effectiveWin) // last segment could be less then state->snd_mss
00507     {
00508         tcpEV << "Cannot send, not enough data for a full segment (SMSS=" << state->snd_mss
00509             << ", in buffer " << buffered << ")\n";
00510         return false;
00511     }
00512 
00513     // start sending 'bytesToSend' bytes
00514     tcpEV << "Will send " << bytesToSend << " bytes (effectiveWindow " << effectiveWin
00515         << ", in buffer " << buffered << " bytes)\n";
00516 
00517     uint32 old_snd_nxt = state->snd_nxt;
00518     ASSERT(bytesToSend>0);
00519 
00520 #ifdef TCP_SENDFRAGMENTS  /* normally undefined */
00521     // make agressive use of the window until the last byte
00522     while (bytesToSend>0)
00523     {
00524         ulong bytes = std::min(bytesToSend, state->snd_mss);
00525         sendSegment(bytes);
00526         bytesToSend -= bytes;
00527     }
00528 #else
00529     // send <MSS segments only if it's the only segment we can send now
00530     // FIXME this should probably obey Nagle's alg -- to be checked
00531     if (bytesToSend <= state->snd_mss)
00532     {
00533         sendSegment(bytesToSend);
00534     }
00535     else
00536     {
00537         // send whole segments only (nagle_enabled)
00538         while (bytesToSend>=state->snd_mss)
00539         {
00540             sendSegment(state->snd_mss);
00541             bytesToSend -= state->snd_mss;
00542         }
00543         // check how many bytes we have - last segment could be less then state->snd_mss
00544         buffered = sendQueue->getBytesAvailable(state->snd_nxt);
00545         if (bytesToSend==buffered && buffered!=0) // last segment?
00546             sendSegment(bytesToSend);
00547         else if (bytesToSend>0)
00548             tcpEV << bytesToSend << " bytes of space left in effectiveWindow\n";
00549     }
00550 #endif
00551 
00552     // remember highest seq sent (snd_nxt may be set back on retransmission,
00553     // but we'll need snd_max to check validity of ACKs -- they must ack
00554     // something we really sent)
00555     state->snd_max = std::max (state->snd_nxt, state->snd_max);
00556     if (unackedVector) unackedVector->record(state->snd_max - state->snd_una);
00557 
00558     // notify (once is enough)
00559     tcpAlgorithm->ackSent();
00560     tcpAlgorithm->dataSent(old_snd_nxt);
00561 
00562     return true;
00563 }
